description: Possibly from stash. Australian from 1893; Boer War military slang. Also may be derived from stushie or stooshie, a Scottish term for a commotion, rumpus, or row.

entries.meaning: (Australia, New Zealand, informal) A fight, an argument.
examples: Barry explained that his friend wasn′t drunk, he′d been in a stoush, had a ding on his head and was covered in money.

verbs.description: stoush (third-person singular simple present stoushes, present participle stoushing, simple past and past participle stoushed)

examples: Wot price ole Ginger Mick? ′E′s done a break— / Gone to the flamin′ war to stoush the foe.
